title: Airbus plants flag in North America with opening of Alabama plant
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Sep 14, 2015, 17:08 BST - UK Markets closed Airbus plants flag in North America with opening of Alabama plant Telegraph – 29 minutes ago 0.0001 0.0000 
The European-based business looks to bag more of the medium-sized airliner market with new factory in Mobile 
Airbus has officially opened its first US assembly plant, strengthening its position in one of the world’s largest aircraft markets. 
The company has spent $600m (£390m) building its plant in the city of Mobile in the Gulf Coast state of Alabama, where it will assemble its A320 family of medium-size single-aisle airliners from sets of major parts built around the world. 
Airbus has set its sights on growing its share of the North American market for new airliners, which it estimates is worth £751bn over the next 20 years. 
The company predicts the region will need almost 6,000 new jets over the period, with 4,730 of them likely to be in the A320 class. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is this huge sector that Airbus is targeting with the Mobile plant. About one in five of all airliners currently flying in the US is made by Airbus but the company wants this figure to rise to more than half, in line with its share of the global market. 
= 'American manufacturer' = 
“Airbus is now a truly American manufacturer,” said Fabrice Brégier, president and chief executive of the business. “This is the most significant and game-changing event in US aerospace in decades.” 
The plant has 260 staff at the moment working on the first two aircraft to be produced there, but staff levels at Mobile will rise to more than 1,000 by the end of 2017, when it will produce one new A320 a week. All these aircraft will go to US customers. 
Despite the expense of establishing itself in Alabama, Airbus denied that location was a major selling point for customers. 
Barry Ecclestone, the British president of Airbus Americas, said setting up in Mobile had had a “very positive impact” on US airlines looking to buy new jets but added: “It’s difficult to know if we have secured an order because the airliners will be built in Mobile. We have had customers who are very excited to be able to say the aircraft will be built in Mobile when they announced the order. 
“In a dead heat where all the other factors are the same, an airline that might have traditionally gone Boeing (NYSE: BA - news ) could be picking us because our aircraft will be built in Alabama.” 
The company brushed off concerns about the extra costs and time incurred by shipping major components to Alabama in order to assemble its planes. 
“We will manage; we know how to have a competitive final assembly line," said Mr Brégier. "When we put it all together - exchange rates, efficiencies, salary costs, budget costs - they are all part of our competitiveness.” 
Airbus has gained incentives including $150m in tax breaks and staff training paid for by the local authorities, but Allan McArtor, chairman of Airbus Americas, said this was not a major factor in the decision to locate in Mobile. 
= Defence = 
Airbus had previously earmarked Mobile for production of air-to-air refuelling tankers when the company won the contract to build the jets for the US air force in 2008, but this decision was latter reversed, with Boeing being selected for the huge deal. 
Beginning production in the US would create leverage for Airbus should it try to access the lucrative US defence market, Mr McArtor added. 
“Having industrial capacity in the US clearly gives us an advantage,” he said. “It gives us political cachet on Capitol Hill and it makes a big difference having your flagpole planted here.” 
But he denied Mobile signalled a stepping up in the fight between Airbus and Boeing. 
“This in not about poking a finger in Boeing’s eye,” he said. “[Mobile] is an opportunity for us. Our strategy is not driven by what Boeing does or is perceived to be doing.”
